facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 28, 1960 by Kapur, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. November 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J. - This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta

facts.text: Reference made by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under s. 66(1) of Income-tax Act to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta in a reference made by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Question referred: Whether Tribunal right in holding Rs. 61,818 spent by assessee to train Indian boys as jockeys not constituting business expenses allowable under s. 10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: The following question was referred Whether in the facts and circumstances of this case, the Appellate Tribunal was right in holding that Rs. 61,818 spent by the assessee to train Indian boys as jockeys, did number companystitute expenses of the business of the assessee allowable under s. 10 2  xv ?

facts.text: High Court answered the question in favour of the respondent (assessee).

anchor.surface_text: which was answered in favour of the respondent. The Commissioner is the appellant before us and the assessee is the respondent. The respondent is an association of persons whose business is to hold race meetings in Calcutta on a companymercial basis.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax is appellant; assessee is respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner is the appellant before us and the assessee is the respondent. The respondent is an association of persons whose business is to hold race meetings in Calcutta on a companymercial basis.

facts.text: Respondent is an association of persons whose business is to hold race meetings in Calcutta on commercial basis.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is an association of persons whose business is to hold race meetings in Calcutta on a companymercial basis. It holds two series of race meetings during the two seasons of the year. The respondent does number own any horses and therefore does number employ jockeys but they are employed by owners and trainers of horses which are run in the races.

facts.text: Respondent holds two series of race meetings during the two seasons of the year.

anchor.surface_text: It holds two series of race meetings during the two seasons of the year. The respondent does number own any horses and therefore does number employ jockeys but they are employed by owners and trainers of horses which are run in the races.

facts.text: Respondent does not own any horses and does not employ jockeys; jockeys employed by owners and trainers.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent does number own any horses and therefore does number employ jockeys but they are employed by owners and trainers of horses which are run in the races. It is a matter of some importance to the respondent that there should be jockeys available to the owners with sufficient skill and experience because the success of races to a companysiderable extent depends upon the experience and skill of a jockey who rides a horse in a race.

facts.text: Success of races depends to considerable extent on experience and skill of jockeys.

anchor.surface_text: It is a matter of some importance to the respondent that there should be jockeys available to the owners with sufficient skill and experience because the success of races to a companysiderable extent depends upon the experience and skill of a jockey who rides a horse in a race. Because it was of the opinion that there was a risk of the jockeys becoming unavailable and that such unavailability would seriously affect its business which might result in its closing down the business,

facts.text: In 1948, respondent established a school for training Indian boys as jockeys to ensure availability for race meetings.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore in 1948, it, established a school for the training of Indian boys as jockeys so that after their training they might be available for purposes of race meetings held under its auspices. The school, however, did number prove a success and after having been in existence for three years it was closed down.

facts.text: School did not prove a success and was closed down after three years.

anchor.surface_text: The school, however, did number prove a success and after having been in existence for three years it was closed down. During the year ending March 31, 1949, the respondent spent a sum of Rs. 62,818 on the running of its school and claimed that amount as a deduction under s. 10 2  xv  of the Income- tax Act

facts.text: During year ending March 31, 1949, respondent spent Rs. 62,818 on running the school.

anchor.surface_text: During the year ending March 31, 1949, the respondent spent a sum of Rs. 62,818 on the running of its school and claimed that amount as a deduction under s. 10 2  xv  of the Income- tax Act and also in the assessment under the Business Profits Tax for the chargeable accounting period ending March 31, 1949.

facts.text: Claim for deduction of Rs. 62,818 disallowed by Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was disallowed by the Income Tax Officer and on appeal by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and also by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. At the instancc of the respondent the question already quoted was referred to the High Court and was answered in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: Claim disallowed on appeal by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: and on appeal by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and also by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Claim disallowed by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: and also by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. At the instancc of the respondent the question already quoted was referred to the High Court

facts.text: Tribunal found it was not the business of respondent to provide jockeys to owners and trainers.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that it was number the business of the respondent to provide jockeys to owners and trainers, that the jockeys trained in the respondents school were number bound to ride only in the races run by the respondent and that the benefit, if any, which accrued was of an enduring nature.

facts.text: Tribunal found jockeys trained not bound to ride only in respondent's races.

anchor.surface_text: that the jockeys trained in the respondents school were number bound to ride only in the races run by the respondent and that the benefit, if any, which accrued was of an enduring nature. It also found that the respondent had been companyducting race meetings since long,

facts.text: Tribunal found benefit of training was of enduring nature.

anchor.surface_text: and that the benefit, if any, which accrued was of an enduring nature.

facts.text: Tribunal found respondent had been conducting race meetings since long.

anchor.surface_text: It also found that the respondent had been companyducting race meetings since long, that it was number the case of the assessee that if it did number train jockeys they would become unavailable

facts.text: Before Appellate Assistant Commissioner, respondent contended expenditure to promote efficient Indian jockeys and prevent races abandonment due to scarcity.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, it was companytended by the respondent, that the reason for incurring the expenditure was to promote efficient Indian jockeys and it was in the interest of the respondent to see that the races are number abandoned on account of the scarcity of jockeys.

facts.text: Tribunal stated it was not the case of respondent that jockeys would become unavailable without training.

anchor.surface_text: In the order of the Tribunal it is stated that this was number the case of the respondent, and therefore when the respondent wanted paragraph 5 of the statement to be substituted by the following It was the case of the assessee that unless it trained Indian Jockeys,

facts.text: Tribunal refused to substitute paragraph 5 of statement as proposed by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal did number agree to do so. Counsel for the appellant raised three points before us  1  The question as to whether an item of expenditure is wholly and exclusively laid out for the purposes of business or number is a question of fact

facts.text: Supreme Court held expenditure was wholly and exclusively for purpose of respondent's business, allowable deduction.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court has rightly held that the expenditure claimed was one which was wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of the respondents business. It was to prevent the threatened extinction of the business of the respondent.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 20, 1957, of the Calcutta High a Court in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1956.

This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta in a reference made by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act.
This appeal is brought by special leave against that judgment.

holdings.text: In our opinion the High Court has rightly held that the expenditure claimed was one which was wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of the respondents business. It was to prevent the threatened extinction of the business of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expenditure on training jockeys to avert scarcity and business extinction is wholly and exclusively for business purposes under s.10(2)(xv), justified by commercial expediency even if benefiting third parties or indirect, supported by precedents like Chandulal Keshavlal, Atherton, Morgan v. Tate Lyle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal erred in law by misapplying scope of 'wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of the assessee's business'; its finding not pure question of fact.

holdings.text: any expenditure which was incurred for preventing the extinction of the respondents business would, in our opinion, be expenditure wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of the business of the assessee and would be an allowable deduction.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore any expenditure which was incurred for preventing the extinction of the respondents business would, in our opinion, be expenditure wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of the business of the assessee and would be an allowable deduction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expenditure to preserve business from extinction qualifies as deductible even if not direct or immediate benefit, per commercial expediency doctrine.

precedents.cited_proposition: in order to justify a deduction the disbursement must be for reasons of commercial expediency it may be voluntary but incurred for the assessees business and if the expense is incurred for the purpose of the business of the assessee it does not matter that the payment also enures to the benefit of a third party

precedents.cited_proposition: a sum of money expended, not of necessity and with a view to a direct and immediate benefit to the trade, but voluntarily and on the ground of commercial expediency and in order indirectly to facilitate the carrying on of the business may yet be expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the trade

precedents.cited_proposition: the object of the expenditure being to preserve the assets of the company from seizure and so to enable it to carry on its business and earning profits, the expense was an admissible deduction being wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of the companys trade
